paHar86AQTOgKLELuntwUw.text: If your in Raouls for a coffee and a chat with your friends, or for a quiet lonely breakfast, Raouls seems to be good for every occasion. I thoroughly enjoyed the bagels, and the chocolate milkshake is just what you need every now and then. As it is in Maida Vale, the other customers are very posh, and the waiters reflect their slightly upturned-nose attitude. Despite this, one cannot deny that the food makes up for any thing else that may be wrong.

iml53tMAMUsZQ97GBQgNJQ.text: The food here is quite nice but the service is really disappointing. We went for brunch, it was quite busy and the only table available when we got to the front of the queue was for 3 people - we were told we could sit at it anyway. The food was good - freshly squeezed orange juice, good coffee and good english breakfast. However, after we'd eaten but while we were waiting for more coffee they asked us to move to another table, which we didn't want to do, and they were so forceful we decided to leave. We didn't pay the optional service charge which resulted in a heated debate with the member of staff who couldn't understand why we didn't want to pay. It's shame, but we won't be going back.

4HOdQPNVQ7DEdjzsVc2d1w.text: I like to eat breakfast at this cosy cafe on a saturday morning (sat as it's busier on sun). They do all sorts of breakfast variety and their eggs are specially imported from italy and so the egg yolk is really yellow / orange. I love eating here with a cuppa. On late afternoon, I love having a slice of their New York Cheese Cake with some tea. Perfect, cosy, and not expensive.

v2ehikv1uUij9Erey1Lt_A.text: Great food. Expensive but good quality.

TmVwxykdkQDFWPrzLHQZ-Q.text: First off its my first time here so i have to be firm and fair so here it goes. First off it was an ok spot the food was ok i got the smoked salmon scrambled eggs and toast it was good but im so use to americanized food i forgot to order to my liking soooooo i guess thats my fault. The other thing was the bathroom location and journey you have to take to get to it (be careful the steps are made for infant feet) other than that it was clean and served its purpose lls

CVBN3lt6r9hGXC-A8E-3Kw.text: The service at Raoul's is especially poor, even by London standards. The staff don't say hello when you enter and say as little as possible. The last time I was there our juice and coffee took more than 15 minutes to arrive and the waitress didn't notice or care when I asked her about it. There are tons of staff here but I've never seen them smile or do more than take orders and bring the bill.I live nearby and have been a few times because it is convenient, rather than nice. The food isn't really good enough to bear the poor service.

j3eo2YEB1FzDxDbWJcVYig.text: This is very difficult for me to write.  This deli has many great things: olive paste, hummus, sun blushed tomatoes, eggs, cheeses, etc. Lattes and juice also good.  The pasta is expensive but tasty.  Because I live in the neighborhood and work strange hours, I am here almost daily. Yes, it's exorbitant. But it's also convenient, and as an American, you know how addicted we are to ease of use, ease of access, and cartoons with lots of BLAMS and POWS and MOZZARELLA.  The problem with Raoul's is the cunning and cruel manager, who is a complete tool, a black hole of light and happiness, and world class jerk.  Though I've spent literally thousands of pounds in the store over the last two years, he barely acknowledges my presence (or anyone else's).  I don't care; but is it too much to smile once in a while?  I've seen him slam phones, scold workers that they missed a spot on the glass door, and act horribly to countless members of his staf fand paying customers. There have literally been dozens of new staff -- the turnover is appalling. Each week there are new people making the lattes.  I think the Americancasualty  rate at Omaha Beach during D-Day was less.  And I don't blame them.  And least many of my brave fellow Americans had their misery ended quickly with a Jerry bullet between the eyes.When the manager is not on premises, there is actually a little bit of life, happiness, a few furtive grins even, by the indentured servants. But when Bungholio, the darkling prince, is snarling and sneering and generally acting like someone's shoved a watermelon-sized pepper up his gorgonzola... then the experience is about as pleasant as watching a tipsy Wayne Rooney scope out the octogenarian talent at the Lady Veterans of WWI's Bi-Monthly  Bingo and Jello Fest -- "Oh please don't leave without trying the jellied eels, Wayne!" Bingo! We've got a winner!Where was I? Oh yes. Sorry.  Raoul's.  Some brilliant food.  Some brilliant counter help. And one of Satan's own lieutenants (minus the sense of humour) running the place. I wouldn't hire this guy to oversee the kitchen of a penal colony on Mars.  His negative energy leaves a sour taste in my mouth that even the sublime scorched almond candies can't erase.  Does England still banish undesirables to America and Australia?  Can't the Home Office deport him?  But still, like a dog to his vomit, I return.  So maybe I'm the one with the problem.

3F_i8bK8IukslHlR8Jqwqw.text: I have not eaten at the restaurant but do frequent the deli as there is one chicken dish I order quite regularly. I have no complaints about the food but the staff are so bad I am not sure how this place stays in business. Really bad attitude from the staff, apparently there is no manager, the owner of Raoul's runs the deli. Awful job as her staff have no idea how to interact with customers. They are surly, rude and inefficient.

aLwNK6AO9ZrKljuyq0ulpQ.text: A friend and myself decided on meet here for dinner as she lives nearby. Overall, the experience was bad. The ambience and decor was simple and expected. I ordered the 8oz free range hamburger with fries and an extra portion of roasted Mediterranean vegetables. My friend had the pan-fried cod and a side order of spinach. My burger was cooked medium as requested. However, it was very dry and just tasted very plain. The roasted veg was expected. My friend's cod was slightly overcooked and the spinach just looked and tasted pathetic. The prices of the mains were from £15-£25, and for the poor quality, it was just not worth it. Service was also subpar. While the one waitress who waited on us was nice, the other 2 just looked miserable to be there. They couldn't muster a smile or looked at us when we arrived, were dining or left. Overall, for this price point, this place is expensive and disappointing particularly for this area in London. I would go as far to say tourist trap restaurants in Central London like Leicester Square serve better food. Come here only if you wish to be served school cafeteria standard food at 3-4 times the price.

HdV7Rv3yYocJnsEtR1tyNQ.text: This is my local brunch joint, and I desperately want it to be good. I've been here a number times and my experience each time has been marred by the service. Like a lady addicted to bad boys I keep giving it one more chance, only to be disappointed,On the plus side the food is pleasant and the menu is wide ranging. However the food isn't particularly cheap (around £7 for a welsh rarebit - effectively cheese on toast!), and although it's good, it is not exceptional enough to make it worth the slopish service. Raoul's is obviously busiest on Sunday, the day the good lord decreed brunch-day, but I expect them to cope. This afternoon I had to attract the staff's attention for them to take our order, after waiting for 15 minutes I realised it was not going to happen without any intervention. Then after they brought out everyone else's food, I had to remind them about my order. Very frustrating and also it made me feel very uncomfortable asking. Unfortunately I am sure I'll be back, their eggs benedict with smoke salmon is just my type and keeps making eyes at me.  That will be your final chance Raoul, you better treat me good next time.

Lv7L2Gu_Q9nyvp90xdQ6IQ.text: When staying with family in London, we made a stop at Raoul's  each morning before heading out to see the city. I can't speak for the breakfast and lunch offerings, but the lattes were fantastic (caffeine fiends should request an extra shot; these are on the mild side), entirely lacking that lovely charred Starbuck's flavor I typically have to settle for when in strange lands. The below reviews are spot-on about the service, however. They do seem a bit put out when you have special needs, like, say, ordering? But they still manage three stars for the surprise of wheat-free chocolate cake. For a girl with a wheat allergy, this was an unexpected delicacy that practically rendered the bad service null and void. (Note: for kinder and quicker service, try Raoul's deli/bakery across the street. Same great espresso, even more treats for the road.)

X3YDU-rUBfF7fKf2LzMRJw.text: I live right down the street and come to Raouls every now and again. Was initially enticed by the interior, and the fact that the lettings agent who showed us this place mentioned it. It was a treat to have a good sandwich when we first moved to the neighborhood, but since then I've been a few times, but the food's been mediocre ever since the first time. The service, as people have commented, is slow and tired. It's a nice atmosphere, but I'd rather go across the street to Vicki's!

5-qozfVXM4hG7nQkw9idFw.text: Raoul's is a nice restaurant. It's perhaps a bit too expensive for what you get, but the food is fairly okay. I was a bit disappointed by the burger, but the other meal a had there was quite good. I also like the simple interior. On Sundays it always looks very busy during the day.

sQ2YkL2djENigBK-cZDEaA.text: Dont be fooled by the name, Raoul's Cafe is NOT a cafe. It might be popular at breakfast and lunch times but the prices certainly do not reflect that of a cafe. If I'm paying above average prices for food I expect the service to be exceptional. Sadly this isn't the case at Raoul- sometimes the service is OK and other times the staff are just rude. It's a shame because the food is really good and the french toast is probably the  best I have ever had.If you like to celeb watch, Raoul's Cafe is the ideal place to brunch with the stars, I have spotted Sienna Miller there a few times. Raoul's will never be a regular haunt for me because there are plenty of other places that manage to provide good food and good service.

wDBUTBIG55bxNrlzldqekQ.text: It's cramped and crowded. Which makes the New York like atmosphere.The breakfast menu is extensive and reasonably priced.The portobello mushrooms on toast excellent as is the full English breakfast.It's one of the best out of hotel breakfasts in town.And it's in a great village atmosphere.Step over to their Deli / Patisserie or the organic stores around.

t1Bq41K-YJJHAg4YzUd0sA.text: Coffee is wonderful. IF it ever arrives. Last time I agreed to meet friends here, they called to say they were running late, so I ordered a Latte. Nothing complicated, no additional instructions, just "a Latte, please" The waiter turned on his heel, and didn't even say acknowledge me, nod at me or anything! Ten minutes later, a girl arrived, asked if she could help. I said "well, I ordered a Latte with your colleague, but it hasn't arrived" she goes off to ask. He growls that of course he remembers, but he has other orders to do. (funny that, i was the first person in the place)15 minutes pass, friends arrive, order their coffee. Mine STILL hasn't arrived, so i say cancel the coffee, I'd like Earl grey with my breakfast. (coffee and eggs isn't a great combo.) Attitude from the waiter.. you ordered it, you must pay for it blah blah.. I wouldn't mind if the damn thing was on the table!! So, to breakfast... as usual, the eggs royale / salmon benedict whatever you want to call them, were lovely. nice hollandaise, slightly soft muffin, but not a problem. Then there's the small matter of side orders. I fancied some spinach.. £4!!!!!!!!! for two spoonfuls of decidedly average steamed spinach. not good.And my friend asked if she could have an extra poached egg with her scrambles- oh no, no changes to the menu. (she was more than happy to pay, but wasn't allowed) I have tried and tried with Raouls Maida Vale, this will be my last visit- there are so many more wonderful places not to need to waste time and money being treated like a fool. *Hammersmith and Notting Hill have much better service, but still maintain the awkward no changes policy.

hqMhtUzuu4BnxQJLmjDEQg.text: Great place for breakfeast or brunch. Tuscan yellow eggs particularly nice. Good outdoor space. Dinner less recommended with below average food. Very inefficient service.

iZQs8XR85JD0RPRPW8cnAg.text: If image, posing, looking good, cool decor, good looking people, flashy but decent food, that is definitely not cheap but also not too overpriced then this is the place for you. It is a place that is hot on looks, trendyness and in a way a place to be seen at, that is loved by people who want that kind of thing. If that is your thing then this is probably the place to be in Little Venice and lots of people love it. If you are into the understated taste thing which is also on the value end of the spectrum then there are other places

sU7OgTxXQJ9S51ZxCMVa0g.text: I have known Raoul's Deli - as it has been called for the past 7 / 8 years - for a long time and I have to say, this is such jewel in the area. We feel so lucky to have such a place offering so many things and it keeps offering more...A lovely cheese counter and excellent cooked dishes. A bit pricey if you have to eat there every day, but heck... how many of us can't be bothered to cook after a long day at work.The Cafe(s) - 3 so far and counting - is one of the best in London for brunch and a quick dinner. The food is always fresh and good, no wonder so many celebrities can be seen there. Be prepared to queue at weekends...

nHhjwOnADnPoA5dmYVNQsQ.text: thanks, yelp, for pointing us to a great breakfast/brunch spot on our second day of vaca. only a couple stops away from our hotel at edgware road, the walk from the warwick avenue station was a pleasant way to get the blood flowing, too -- a tree-lined snooty (i mean that in a good way!) street (that kinda reminded me of the upper east side in NYC). it was sort of late-ish in the morning on a weekday so it was relatively empty, but i got the impression (perhaps wrong) that it's a neighborhood joint that has its fair share of regulars. i don't remember what i got (i guess it wasn't that memorable?) but my friend got the eggs benedict, which she claimed was the best she's ever had. she also got the fruit salad but didn't like it because she said there was a funny (after?)taste. i tried it, however, and didn't find anything wrong with it at all, so *shrug*.service was attentive although i wouldn't say particularly speedy. i wouldn't call this a cafe, more like a bistro. it has an upscale vibe (only to be cheapened by a gaggle of american late-teen girls [i can say that, i'm american] *snort*).not quite sure i'd come again the next time i'm in town since there are so many other places to try, but i could easily see myself being a regular if i lived close by.

O17tbIHAi_sHhLLSVc2k4g.text: Possibly the best cafe/restaurant in the Warwick Ave/Maida Vale area. Definitely go there for brunch and try the eggs. It can get really busy on weekends so prepare to wait to be seated but it's definitely worth the wait.

IMo_N_My_0o2SYfZJJYakw.text: I went to Raouls with high hopes and was very impressed with the decor inside and the menu is great for breakfast containing kippers, smoked haddock, eggs benedict etc Having ordered drinks and food (great smoothie range) I waited as the staff buzzed around me. Sure enough my cutlery was delivered but no drinks or food. Eventually after about 15 minutes I approached the waiter who had taken my order and guess what, the order had been lost. Reading through other reviews on qype this seems to be a habit of theirs! In the end the food was very good and they knocked the drinks off the bill but I won't hurry back.

OuR9QANzHKSWDEiVDoa6aA.text: REVIEW OF RAOULS RESTAURANT CLIFTON RD If there's one word that springs to mind to describe my experience of this place, then it has to be 'anticlimax'. Allow me to explain As you've probably gathered by now if youve read any of my other reviews, I've grown up in Maida Vale and so these local restaurants/eateries have been pretty much part of my visual landscape for almost two decades now. When you see something over and over day in day out, it begins to weave itself into the tapestry of your life, more than often, being something that you just take for granted, visually that is. Think of any road you may walk down every day in your life. Have you ever stopped to study each and every door and building and object that lies along the way? Because I can assure you, you will be surprised at what you might find. Things you've been walking past for years, that you never knew existed. To give a very diluted example of this, I only recently noticed by accident, that each and every black baluster making up the long line of balustrade that runs the full length of Hyde Park adjacent to Rotten Row separating the row from the cycle path, has written on it, names of deceased people. The names are written in black in the same colour as the balustrade, so unless you actually bend over and take a good look at them, it's hardly noticeable. And this is not advisable, because you will probably end up with your name on one of them too, having been mowed down by one of the oncoming cyclists. Not the best of examples (I can think of loads more, like the river that runs in the air right through Sloane Sq tube station), but still, it illustrates how we just take things for granted, without ever really truly knowing (or more accurately, bothering ourselves to know) what lurks behind the facade that lines our streets. For me, Raouls cafe was just this; one of the few jewel-like corner-stones that laid the foundations down for the character and soul of the now-ruined Clifton Rd, in Little Venice; along with Vickis cafe (now Molly's!) across the way, the now non-existent Post office on the corner (the decommissioning of this place was simply a crime), Superfoods, a beautifully quaint, spotless, gleaming 1950's American styled supermarket (complete with background chiming music) that was gobbled up by Tescos around 2004, Cullens, residing just next door, the perfect antidote to the sterilized feel of commercialized supermarket shopping, and the two newsagents that flanked the supermarkets on either side. Raouls was (and still is) Little Venice's flagship restaurant. One of it's remarkable qualities, is that it has this wonderful chameleon-like ability to change it's form, function and guise during the course of the day. In the mornings (I believe this is the best time to experience what Raouls has to offer), it's like one of those New York style breakfast bashers, serving up good quality morning grub (so I've gathered). At lunchtime it magically turns into a bistro! De-deer! Filled with Little Venician mothers nattering away at each other like there's no tomorrow, using words like 'parsimonious'; a smattering of MaidaVale glitterati; local business people etc grabbing a bite to eat whilst simultaneously doing business verbally; and the obligatory local St John's Wood/Maidavale 'rich folk' whiling away their free time (and daddy's money) whilst casually sipping away at the current fashionable version of a particular style of coffee. Come late afternoon, Raouls suffers a slight bout of multiple-personality-disorder, it doesn't know which way to turn, having a bit of a problem deciding whether or not to remain as restaurant for the remainder of the day, or slip back into it's cafeteria attire for a couple of hours or so. Food is available all day, but I think afternoons is teatime here, to be honest. Then in the evening, its full-on restaurant time, right up until last orders which is around 10.30pm to 11pm. I had a meal here once, through no choice of my own. My father was renovating his house round the corner and it was temporarily gutted out. We'd been living off takeaways for weeks, and were bored of the same ones, so we decided to try Raouls out, reluctantly may I add; for the first time in twenty years. I'd been there a couple of times before with my mum, but just for a glass of wine or something like that, not food. We were late, and so scurried down the hill to try and make it in time. As usual, the place was packed out and really bustling. The sonourous blend of clinking and clanking coupled with the mild roar of alcohol induced conversation completely blasted me the second I opened the front door; not to mention the accompanying gust of stares, and the gust of wind that followed it, blowing my Beatles hairbob into a freshly erected Amy Winehouse bouffant, plastering my innocent looking physiognomy backwards by a millimeter or two, like I had just recovered from a facelift whilst simultaneously accelerating from 0-2000mph in

RbXRRLszPyP-iqU3hkpflA.text: There are two places called Raoul's on Clifton Road: one is the cafe and the other is its delicatessan counterpart. Monsieur and I have enjoyed brunch at the cafe a few times, but it's pricey for what it is, so come with a full wallet. Personally, I've never had a problem with the cafe staff; they always seem personable and efficient to me. My problem is with the deli staff. In a single word, they are rude. Given that the prices are not exactly cheap, it always astounds me that the rotating staff here can be so inefficient. The blonde-bobbed proprietor is probably to blame. She's perfectly polite to anyone male, but rude as anything to female customers. It's such a joke that it's almost worth buying something here to watch her in action! Last comment - always double check your receipt. They once charged us £20.00 for a chicken but we didn't check the card receipt until we got home and realised their mistake. Needless to say we went straight back to ask for a refund. Summary - good food, good quality, good selection in the deli but terrible service. Cafe has good menu, especially for brunch, nice staff but expensive.

m8cNzkj7OPDDMQ1DWmyCYA.text: Just got to London and perfect spot to eat and day drink! Breakfast was delish! Fresh squeezed in their mimosas.

photos.caption: Photo of Raoul's - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Raoul's - London, United Kingdom

7oVyhJI3vbT8094-x79Oiw.text: Great food great location and the service amazing we had the rib eye stake it was smaller than the American rib eye but tasted better and was cooked perfectly!My wife had the sea bass that was very good

nquH81WXRO2mO5o14r5dog.text: I went to the deli to pick up food and there was clear profiling. I was there with another 2 customers who were treated completely differently from  myself. I am always considerate of those who work in customer service because it is a tough job, but the experience was awful and definitely one of the worst since moving here from the States. A big no no in terms of customer service! Just moved to the neighborhood and will NOT be going back there. Awful!

GY0xyQsuLKQ642V3pSsUDQ.text: I've been here 4x now for breakfast and lunch and it is consistently bad. The service as others have mentioned is terrible. Wait staff is not very happy, you have to flag them down to order anything. The manager is rude, always arguing with customers about their food or Bill. We have seen it 3x! The food is average or worse. There are much better options nearby. We won't be back. This must be why we never have to wait for a table on the weekend for breakfast or lunch like other places- people know it's nothing to write home about!

ekeljv84Y9_6SkFdr7kh6Q.text: Great Service! Good coffee! Delicious breakfast stop after a brisk walk by the canals!Highly recommend for a quality experience!

bPWY_5Ure1W6C0MfWqfpag.text: Good food with an interesting selection of breakfast options. I loved the spinach frittata!Very good service. Attentive and effective. Just what you want to have for a relaxing Sunday morning experience.

photos.caption: Photo of Raoul's - London, United Kingdom. Spinach & feta frittata.
Photo of Raoul's - London, United Kingdom. Good atmosphere and nice service.

gR5yYcMoq5vj4grQnUuo8g.text: I had such an uncomfortable experience at Raoul's this morning that I had to write another review for this place. Not only was it an off day in terms of the food, but the waitress we had was very awkward and rude and kept giving us blank stares. I find that the service tends to be pretty bad most of the times I come here. It's a shame because the Raoul's in Notting Hill is great and I never have an issue with neither the food nor the service there.

mxkIUFJtYNr-wBFs9t7Y_A.text: Met up with a friend for breakfast. I wasn't happy with the service. We had to ask for table water 3 times before it arrived. Additionally the food was a little bland. Wouldn't go out of my way to have this, however, it is an honest meal, something you can make at home. It cost about 8 pounds..

photos.caption: Photo of Raoul's - London, United Kingdom. Vegetarian breakfast
Photo of Raoul's - London, United Kingdom. Chorizo egg and toast!

jfBDUuHUnRShz2oKlKqEHQ.text: We came here for brunch on a Sunday morning. No reservation required. The menu was extensive enough but not overwhelming. The food delicious. I had a frittata Nd my husband had the full English. Each was yummy. We sat outside at a table in the beautiful sunshine. I will be back here for sure and probably take my mom when she's in town.

3h23f2GlKDXiNG0Xo2Q5fw.text: Great place for a late lazy breakfast. Located close to Little Venice, Raouls serves food all day long, however I have only ever had breakfast here. Their fresh orange juice is incredible, ingredients taste fresh, and service is prompt. It is hard to say good things about eggs, after all, it's eggs. Who does a bad job with eggs? So I can offer you this instead: their pies are fresh and taste amazing. I can especially vouch for the banofee pie.

vpKEamLL7ANIijPUXba4Uw.text: On a recent visit here I went for the Eggs Benedict for late breakfast and after a very short time, my food arrived.The Benedict sauce was tasty but very sour and tart, the ham was of a lower grade than I would expect for a supposedly higher-end restaurant. The small portion and lack of presentation/garnish capped it all. One of my pet hates also came my way... grubby finger marks around the plate's edge.Raoul's makes up for the lack of English comprehension of it's staff by just having plenty of them. I find it troubling that the waiters can not grasp my order even when it is a plain old stock item from the menu. God help those with a nut allergy, trying to ascertain ingredients... The restaurant is nicely decorated and well presented. It feels buzzy and lively, even when there are only a few customers present.To be truly fair to Raoul's Deli, I returned a few days later. The meat Mezze I had was really great tasting, but I had to complain that the Kofte kebab was still raw in the middle... after much language barrier based confusion, my plate was grabbed away and reappeared ten minutes later with the same pieces of meat - bite marks 'n all - cooked to "well done".Personally I would have preferred to have continued eating my dish and they could have made me some sufficiently cooked meat. But I did not get a say in that...There may be a time when I return to Raoul's Deli - when I do, I really hope I have the chance to write a positive review - I really want to like this place!N.B. Raoul's pre-adds service charge to bill.No WIFI.

K37a9zAttE3xfke7PshtBw.text: It seems like there is a bit of confusion on here about the different Raoul's in maida vale. This review is not for the restaurant, but for the deli. It's overpriced and just okay. The to-go foods? I prefer Baker and Spice.The meats, olives, and cheese? I'd walk the extra 12 min to Panzer's. It's really the bread, pastries, and coffee I come here for. It's really delicious. But not so delicious I'd leave my neighborhood to try it...if you're in the hood, give it a try. But don't make the trip out here just for raouls. Unless you like cheesy bread sticks. I would come here for the cheesy bread sticks.

-N1n4r-tIrUoiCrAyIfE2g.text: This 'out of time' place seems to be stuck in the 1980's bubble of confused waiters, top end prices for Tesco style ingredients and catering for Gloria Swanson type women with small dogs and mink hats.They need to look at their offer, their staff and the local crowd that want so much to like this place but can't...

wgQIJ4DiqBuw1UA8H_HLLQ.text: We went there for Sunday's brunch. Food was good but not impressive, portions not so big .. But the price was kinda high ! I had eggs florentine. They were good. Not sure I would go back ..

5UjdkrN7FDyIlCL2a32boQ.text: 3 stars for the food, 1 star for the service. We were 4 women for a Monday lunch.  We ordered 1 soup and salad, 1 soup and salmon, chicken piri piri and a sandwich. 3 of us were served and one got nothing-no soup and no salmon. Her chicken noodle soup which was good came when the 3 others were almost finished...so we cancelled the salmon. We were told that she would take the salmon to go. We said...no salmon to go doesn't sound very appetizing. The waiter stormed off and actually pumped his fist at our table to his colleague.  I am going to give him the benefit of the doubt and assume that he was having a bad day and that he actually understood it was the restaurants mistake for not serving one of four dishes with the others and that he is very sorry today.The food was good...but the atmosphere and service were blah.

HTf6-q80x8JZZn9T63LtUw.text: Came here on a beautiful Sunday afternoon with a friend to grab some desserts.I had the brownie w/ cream, and she had the apple strudel. The brownie came out looking rather strange: it was a rectangular cut that looked too flat and too long. It also looked like it had been sitting there for quite a while. Also, the cream had started melting and had already soaked my napkin - which made the napkin useless.The brownie was just the right temperature - obviously microwaved but it doesn't matter - and the cream was just the right sweetness to pair with the brownie. The brownie was rich and moist - and though I was still put off by the look of it, I have nothing to complain about regarding the taste. It was delicious.I assume that the strudel was good as well, as my friend finished it before I was done with mine. The prices weren't cheap, but not extravagant. I would highly recommend the brownie with cream if you are ever trying to decide on a dessert at Raoul's!

py5PjWNCI6pXvUrjwk48DA.text: Service here is very inappropriate! The people don't care and they have no social skills! They always complain about their management (it doesn't exist) and the Italian guy who is called manager is the worst I have seen in my life. Even in the neighbourhood they say the worst things for this place. It's July and they still sell products I have seen at Christmas.

xeLs3PUnoxXXAGD44kE_ag.text: Much more than a deli...This place is gourmet heaven! Place has fresh, high quality foods: Fresh vegetables, fresh pastas & sauces, Deli has salamis, olives, too many wonderful salads for take away to list, cheeses, and there is a bakery counter on the other side of the shop with sinful baked goods. Prices are higher than a normal grocery of course, but you go here if you want quality - especially great stop if you're planning to cook a wonderful, simple italian dinner where a few high quality ingredients go a long way to making a remarkable meal.  Raoul's gourmet restaurant is located directly across the street from the deli. So if you'd rather not fuss with cooking, you browse the deli to see the amazing products and satisfy your appetite at the restaurant :)

IZvMySoKR9DB6wMGOVvq2w.text: Raoul's is a local favorite in a residential area that also has plenty of fans coming in to sample their tasty menu. It's on the small side, seems to always have a queue (good sign the food is good) but worth the short wait. Very friendly staff and quick service.. The deco is trendy modern 60's revival with B&W photos (including a young John Lennon), op-arty leaf wallpaper (in the back section) and custom cut-out wood wall screens. A few outdoor tables are available and a couple of hearty souls were outside in the snow today with their adorable black lab looking anxiously at their bacon! Prices are moderate, reflecting the quality and atmosphere.I had the Eggs Benedict with Smoked Salmon done perfectly. To my delight, they use eggs that have the deepest orange yolks I've ever seen. Google answers indicate this is based on a better diet, possibly including maize, and less stress both of which may also indicate free-range hens. Although marigolds have been known to make the yolk darker, the flavor of the eggs at Raoul's tells me that their eggs would be the free-range version. Delicious! I'm a convert!Across the street is Raoul's Deli for amazing take-out. Their cheesecakes, cakes and pastries look scrumptious. I'll be returning to sample them. Stay tuned for another Raoul's Deli review!

41nkUIYhgnqcuLxTROA-_A.text: Great place to get cold cuts and Machiavelli eggs. It also has deli counter - popular items are chicken escalope and lasagna. Salads are there but much better at baker and spice must a few doors down.  I personally like arancini and porcini mushroom lasagna. I also like the fact that it carries gelupo ice cream. Just don't get any kind of coffee - quite disgusting...
